God dwells in that city; it cannot be destroyed.
    From the very break of day, God will protect it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The nations are in chaos,
    and their kingdoms crumble!
God’s voice thunders,
    and the earth melts!
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord of Heaven’s Armies is here among us;
    the God of Israel is our fortress. Interlude
speaker: Narrator

text:
Come, see the glorious works of the Lord:
    See how he brings destruction upon the world.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
“Be still, and know that I am God!
    I will be honored by every nation.
    I will be honored throughout the world.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord of Heaven’s Armies is here among us;
    the God of Israel is our fortress. Interlude
speaker: Narrator

text:
Come, everyone! Clap your hands!
    Shout to God with joyful praise!
speaker: Narrator

text:
For the Lord Most High is awesome.
    He is the great King of all the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He subdues the nations before us,
    putting our enemies beneath our feet.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He chose the Promised Land as our inheritance,
    the proud possession of Jacob’s descendants, whom he loves. Interlude
speaker: Narrator

text:
God has ascended with a mighty shout.
    The Lord has ascended with trumpets blaring.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Sing praises to God, sing praises;
    sing praises to our King, sing praises!
speaker: Narrator

text:
For God is the King over all the earth.
    Praise him with a psalm.
speaker: Narrator

text:
God reigns above the nations,
    sitting on his holy throne.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The rulers of the world have gathered together
    with the people of the God of Abraham.
For all the kings of the earth belong to God.
    He is highly honored everywhere.
speaker: Narrator

text:
How great is the Lord,
    how deserving of praise,
in the city of our God,
    which sits on his holy mountain!
speaker: Narrator

text:
It is high and magnificent;
    the whole earth rejoices to see it!
Mount Zion, the holy mountain,
    is the city of the great King!
speaker: Narrator

text:
God himself is in Jerusalem’s towers,
    revealing himself as its defender.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The kings of the earth joined forces
    and advanced against the city.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But when they saw it, they were stunned;
    they were terrified and ran away.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They were gripped with terror
    and writhed in pain like a woman in labor.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You destroyed them like the mighty ships of Tarshish
    shattered by a powerful east wind.
speaker: Narrator

text:
We had heard of the city’s glory,
    but now we have seen it ourselves—
    the city of the Lord of Heaven’s Armies.
It is the city of our God;
    he will make it safe forever. Interlude
speaker: Narrator

text:
O God, we meditate on your unfailing love
    as we worship in your Temple.
speaker: Narrator

text:
As your name deserves, O God,
    you will be praised to the ends of the earth.
    Your strong right hand is filled with victory.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let the people on Mount Zion rejoice.
    Let all the towns of Judah be glad
    because of your justice.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Go, inspect the city of Jerusalem.
    Walk around and count the many towers.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Take note of the fortified walls,
    and tour all the citadels,
that you may describe them
    to future generations.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For that is what God is like.
    He is our God forever and ever,
    and he will guide us until we die.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Listen to this, all you people!
    Pay attention, everyone in the world!
speaker: Narrator

text:
High and low,
    rich and poor—listen!
speaker: Narrator

text:
For my words are wise,
    and my thoughts are filled with insight.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I listen carefully to many proverbs
    and solve riddles with inspiration from a harp.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Why should I fear when trouble comes,
    when enemies surround me?
speaker: Narrator

text:
They trust in their wealth
    and boast of great riches.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yet they cannot redeem themselves from death
    by paying a ransom to God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Redemption does not come so easily,
    for no one can ever pay enough
speaker: Narrator

text:
to live forever
    and never see the grave.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Those who are wise must finally die,
    just like the foolish and senseless,
    leaving all their wealth behind.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The grave is their eternal home,
    where they will stay forever.
They may name their estates after themselves,
speaker: Narrator

text:
but their fame will not last.
    They will die, just like animals.
speaker: Narrator

text:
This is the fate of fools,
    though they are remembered as being wise. Interlude
speaker: Narrator

text:
Like sheep, they are led to the grave,
    where death will be their shepherd.
In the morning the godly will rule over them.
    Their bodies will rot in the grave,
    far from their grand estates.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But as for me, God will redeem my life.
    He will snatch me from the power of the grave. Interlude
speaker: Narrator

text:
So don’t be dismayed when the wicked grow rich
    and their homes become ever more splendid.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For when they die, they take nothing with them.
    Their wealth will not follow them into the grave.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In this life they consider themselves fortunate
    and are applauded for their success.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But they will die like all before them
    and never again see the light of day.
speaker: Narrator

text:
People who boast of their wealth don’t understand;
    they will die, just like animals.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord, the Mighty One, is God,
    and he has spoken;
he has summoned all humanity
    from where the sun rises to where it sets.
speaker: Narrator

text:
From Mount Zion, the perfection of beauty,
    God shines in glorious radiance.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Our God approaches,
    and he is not silent.
Fire devours everything in his way,
    and a great storm rages around him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He calls on the heavens above and earth below
    to witness the judgment of his people.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Bring my faithful people to me—
    those who made a covenant with me by giving sacrifices.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then let the heavens proclaim his justice,
    for God himself will be the judge. Interlude
speaker: Narrator

text:
“O my people, listen as I speak.
    Here are my charges against you, O Israel:
    I am God, your God!
speaker: Narrator

text:
I have no complaint about your sacrifices
    or the burnt offerings you constantly offer.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But I do not need the bulls from your barns
    or the goats from your pens.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For all the animals of the forest are mine,
    and I own the cattle on a thousand hills.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I know every bird on the mountains,
    and all the animals of the field are mine.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If I were hungry, I would not tell you,
    for all the world is mine and everything in it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do I eat the meat of bulls?
    Do I drink the blood of goats?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Make thankfulness your sacrifice to God,
    and keep the vows you made to the Most High.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then call on me when you are in trouble,
    and I will rescue you,
    and you will give me glory.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
But God says to the wicked:
“Why bother reciting my decrees
    and pretending to obey my covenant?
speaker: Narrator

text:
For you refuse my discipline
    and treat my words like trash.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When you see thieves, you approve of them,
    and you spend your time with adulterers.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your mouth is filled with wickedness,
    and your tongue is full of lies.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You sit around and slander your brother—
    your own mother’s son.
speaker: Narrator

text:
While you did all this, I remained silent,
    and you thought I didn’t care.
But now I will rebuke you,
    listing all my charges against you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Repent, all of you who forget me,
    or I will tear you apart,
    and no one will help you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But giving thanks is a sacrifice that truly honors me.
    If you keep to my path,
    I will reveal to you the salvation of God.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Have mercy on me, O God,
    because of your unfailing love.
Because of your great compassion,
    blot out the stain of my sins.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Wash me clean from my guilt.
    Purify me from my sin.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For I recognize my rebellion;
    it haunts me day and night.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Against you, and you alone, have I sinned;
    I have done what is evil in your sight.
You will be proved right in what you say,
    and your judgment against me is just.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For I was born a sinner—
    yes, from the moment my mother conceived me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But you desire honesty from the womb,
    teaching me wisdom even there.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Purify me from my sins, and I will be clean;
    wash me, and I will be whiter than snow.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Don’t keep looking at my sins.
    Remove the stain of my guilt.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Create in me a clean heart, O God.
    Renew a loyal spirit within me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not banish me from your presence,
    and don’t take your Holy Spirit from me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Restore to me the joy of your salvation,
    and make me willing to obey you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then I will teach your ways to rebels,
    and they will return to you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Forgive me for shedding blood, O God who saves;
    then I will joyfully sing of your forgiveness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Unseal my lips, O Lord,
    that my mouth may praise you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You do not desire a sacrifice, or I would offer one.
    You do not want a burnt offering.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The sacrifice you desire is a broken spirit.
    You will not reject a broken and repentant heart, O God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Look with favor on Zion and help her;
    rebuild the walls of Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then you will be pleased with sacrifices offered in the right spirit—
    with burnt offerings and whole burnt offerings.
    Then bulls will again be sacrificed on your altar.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Why do you boast about your crimes, great warrior?
    Don’t you realize God’s justice continues forever?
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
You love evil more than good
    and lies more than truth. Interlude
speaker: Narrator

text:
You love to destroy others with your words,
    you liar!
speaker: Narrator

text:
But God will strike you down once and for all.
    He will pull you from your home
    and uproot you from the land of the living. Interlude
speaker: Narrator

text:
The righteous will see it and be amazed.
    They will laugh and say,
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Look what happens to mighty warriors
    who do not trust in God.
They trust their wealth instead
    and grow more and more bold in their wickedness.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
But I am like an olive tree, thriving in the house of God.
    I will always trust in God’s unfailing love.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will praise you forever, O God,
    for what you have done.
I will trust in your good name
    in the presence of your faithful people.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Only fools say in their hearts,
    “There is no God.”
They are corrupt, and their actions are evil;
    not one of them does good!
speaker: Narrator

text:
God looks down from heaven
    on the entire human race;
he looks to see if anyone is truly wise,
    if anyone seeks God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But no, all have turned away;
    all have become corrupt.
No one does good,
    not a single one!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Will those who do evil never learn?
    They eat up my people like bread
    and wouldn’t think of praying to God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Terror will grip them,
    terror like they have never known before.
God will scatter the bones of your enemies.
    You will put them to shame, for God has rejected them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who will come from Mount Zion to rescue Israel?
    When God restores his people,
    Jacob will shout with joy, and Israel will rejoice.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Come with great power, O God, and rescue me!
    Defend me with your might.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Listen to my prayer, O God.
    Pay attention to my plea.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
But God is my helper.
    The Lord keeps me alive!
speaker: Narrator

text:
May the evil plans of my enemies be turned against them.
    Do as you promised and put an end to them.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
For you have rescued me from my troubles
    and helped me to triumph over my enemies.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Listen to my prayer, O God.
    Do not ignore my cry for help!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Please listen and answer me,
    for I am overwhelmed by my troubles.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My enemies shout at me,
    making loud and wicked threats.
They bring trouble on me
    and angrily hunt me down.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My heart pounds in my chest.
    The terror of death assaults me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Fear and trembling overwhelm me,
    and I can’t stop shaking.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Oh, that I had wings like a dove;
    then I would fly away and rest!
speaker: Narrator

text:
I would fly far away
    to the quiet of the wilderness. Interlude
speaker: Narrator

text:
How quickly I would escape—
    far from this wild storm of hatred.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Confuse them, Lord, and frustrate their plans,
    for I see violence and conflict in the city.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Its walls are patrolled day and night against invaders,
    but the real danger is wickedness within the city.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Everything is falling apart;
    threats and cheating are rampant in the streets.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It is not an enemy who taunts me—
    I could bear that.
It is not my foes who so arrogantly insult me—
    I could have hidden from them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Instead, it is you—my equal,
    my companion and close friend.
speaker: Narrator

text:
What good fellowship we once enjoyed
    as we walked together to the house of God.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
But I will call on God,
    and the Lord will rescue me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Morning, noon, and night
    I cry out in my distress,
    and the Lord hears my voice.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
God, who has ruled forever,
    will hear me and humble them. Interlude
For my enemies refuse to change their ways;
    they do not fear God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
As for my companion, he betrayed his friends;
    he broke his promises.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His words are as smooth as butter,
    but in his heart is war.
His words are as soothing as lotion,
    but underneath are daggers!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Give your burdens to the Lord,
    and he will take care of you.
    He will not permit the godly to slip and fall.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But you, O God, will send the wicked
    down to the pit of destruction.
Murderers and liars will die young,
    but I am trusting you to save me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
O God, have mercy on me,
    for people are hounding me.
    My foes attack me all day long.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I am constantly hounded by those who slander me,
    and many are boldly attacking me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But when I am afraid,
    I will put my trust in you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I praise God for what he has promised.
    I trust in God, so why should I be afraid?
    What can mere mortals do to me?
speaker: Narrator

text:
They are always twisting what I say;
    they spend their days plotting to harm me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They come together to spy on me—
    watching my every step, eager to kill me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Don’t let them get away with their wickedness;
    in your anger, O God, bring them down.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You keep track of all my sorrows.
    You have collected all my tears in your bottle.
    You have recorded each one in your book.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My enemies will retreat when I call to you for help.
    This I know: God is on my side!
speaker: Narrator

text:
I praise God for what he has promised;
    yes, I praise the Lord for what he has promised.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I trust in God, so why should I be afraid?
    What can mere mortals do to me?
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will fulfill my vows to you, O God,
    and will offer a sacrifice of thanks for your help.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For you have rescued me from death;
    you have kept my feet from slipping.
So now I can walk in your presence, O God,
    in your life-giving light.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Have mercy on me, O God, have mercy!
    I look to you for protection.
I will hide beneath the shadow of your wings
    until the danger passes by.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I cry out to God Most High,
    to God who will fulfill his purpose for me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He will send help from heaven to rescue me,
    disgracing those who hound me. Interlude
My God will send forth his unfailing love and faithfulness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I am surrounded by fierce lions
    who greedily devour human prey—
whose teeth pierce like spears and arrows,
    and whose tongues cut like swords.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Be exalted, O God, above the highest heavens!
    May your glory shine over all the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My enemies have set a trap for me.
    I am weary from distress.
They have dug a deep pit in my path,
    but they themselves have fallen into it. Interlude
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Wake up, my heart!
    Wake up, O lyre and harp!
    I will wake the dawn with my song.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will thank you, Lord, among all the people.
    I will sing your praises among the nations.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For your unfailing love is as high as the heavens.
    Your faithfulness reaches to the clouds.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Be exalted, O God, above the highest heavens.
    May your glory shine over all the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Justice—do you rulers know the meaning of the word?
    Do you judge the people fairly?
speaker: Narrator

text:
No! You plot injustice in your hearts.
    You spread violence throughout the land.
speaker: Narrator

text:
These wicked people are born sinners;
    even from birth they have lied and gone their own way.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They spit venom like deadly snakes;
    they are like cobras that refuse to listen,
speaker: Narrator

text:
ignoring the tunes of the snake charmers,
    no matter how skillfully they play.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Break off their fangs, O God!
    Smash the jaws of these lions, O Lord!
speaker: Narrator

text:
May they disappear like water into thirsty ground.
    Make their weapons useless in their hands.
speaker: Narrator

text:
May they be like snails that dissolve into slime,
    like a stillborn child who will never see the sun.
speaker: Narrator

text:
God will sweep them away, both young and old,
    faster than a pot heats over burning thorns.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The godly will rejoice when they see injustice avenged.
    They will wash their feet in the blood of the wicked.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Rescue me from my enemies, O God.
    Protect me from those who have come to destroy me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Rescue me from these criminals;
    save me from these murderers.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They have set an ambush for me.
    Fierce enemies are out there waiting, Lord,
    though I have not sinned or offended them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I have done nothing wrong,
    yet they prepare to attack me.
    Wake up! See what is happening and help me!
speaker: Narrator

text:
O Lord God of Heaven’s Armies, the God of Israel,
    wake up and punish those hostile nations.
    Show no mercy to wicked traitors. Interlude
speaker: Narrator

text:
They come out at night,
    snarling like vicious dogs
    as they prowl the streets.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
But Lord, you laugh at them.
    You scoff at all the hostile nations.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You are my strength; I wait for you to rescue me,
    for you, O God, are my fortress.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In his unfailing love, my God will stand with me.
    He will let me look down in triumph on all my enemies.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Because of the sinful things they say,
    because of the evil that is on their lips,
let them be captured by their pride,
    their curses, and their lies.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Destroy them in your anger!
    Wipe them out completely!
Then the whole world will know
    that God reigns in Israel. Interlude
speaker: Narrator

text:
My enemies come out at night,
    snarling like vicious dogs
    as they prowl the streets.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They scavenge for food
    but go to sleep unsatisfied.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But as for me, I will sing about your power.
    Each morning I will sing with joy about your unfailing love.
For you have been my refuge,
    a place of safety when I am in distress.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
You have rejected us, O God, and broken our defenses.
    You have been angry with us; now restore us to your favor.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You have shaken our land and split it open.
    Seal the cracks, for the land trembles.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You have been very hard on us,
    making us drink wine that sent us reeling.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But you have raised a banner for those who fear you—
    a rallying point in the face of attack. Interlude
speaker: Narrator

text:
Now rescue your beloved people.
    Answer and save us by your power.
speaker: Narrator

text:
God has promised this by his holiness:
“I will divide up Shechem with joy.
    I will measure out the valley of Succoth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Gilead is mine,
    and Manasseh, too.
Ephraim, my helmet, will produce my warriors,
    and Judah, my scepter, will produce my kings.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But Moab, my washbasin, will become my servant,
    and I will wipe my feet on Edom
    and shout in triumph over Philistia.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who will bring me into the fortified city?
    Who will bring me victory over Edom?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Have you rejected us, O God?
    Will you no longer march with our armies?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Oh, please help us against our enemies,
    for all human help is useless.
speaker: Narrator

text:
With God’s help we will do mighty things,
    for he will trample down our foes.
speaker: Narrator

text:
O God, listen to my cry!
    Hear my prayer!
speaker: Narrator

text:
From the ends of the earth,
    I cry to you for help
    when my heart is overwhelmed.
Lead me to the towering rock of safety,
speaker: Narrator

text:
for you are my safe refuge,
    a fortress where my enemies cannot reach me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let me live forever in your sanctuary,
    safe beneath the shelter of your wings! Interlude
speaker: Narrator

text:
For you have heard my vows, O God.
    You have given me an inheritance reserved for those who fear your name.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Add many years to the life of the king!
    May his years span the generations!
speaker: Narrator

text:
May he reign under God’s protection forever.
    May your unfailing love and faithfulness watch over him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then I will sing praises to your name forever
    as I fulfill my vows each day.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I wait quietly before God,
    for my victory comes from him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He alone is my rock and my salvation,
    my fortress where I will never be shaken.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So many enemies against one man—
    all of them trying to kill me.
To them I’m just a broken-down wall
    or a tottering fence.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They plan to topple me from my high position.
    They delight in telling lies about me.
They praise me to my face
    but curse me in their hearts. Interlude
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let all that I am wait quietly before God,
    for my hope is in him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He alone is my rock and my salvation,
    my fortress where I will not be shaken.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My victory and honor come from God alone.
    He is my refuge, a rock where no enemy can reach me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
O my people, trust in him at all times.
    Pour out your heart to him,
    for God is our refuge. Interlude
speaker: Narrator

text:
Common people are as worthless as a puff of wind,
    and the powerful are not what they appear to be.
If you weigh them on the scales,
    together they are lighter than a breath of air.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Don’t make your living by extortion
    or put your hope in stealing.
And if your wealth increases,
    don’t make it the center of your life.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
unfailing love, O Lord, is yours.
Surely you repay all people
    according to what they have done.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
I have seen you in your sanctuary
    and gazed upon your power and glory.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your unfailing love is better than life itself;
    how I praise you!
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will praise you as long as I live,
    lifting up my hands to you in prayer.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You satisfy me more than the richest feast.
    I will praise you with songs of joy.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I lie awake thinking of you,
    meditating on you through the night.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Because you are my helper,
    I sing for joy in the shadow of your wings.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I cling to you;
    your strong right hand holds me securely.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But those plotting to destroy me will come to ruin.
    They will go down into the depths of the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They will die by the sword
    and become the food of jackals.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But the king will rejoice in God.
    All who swear to tell the truth will praise him,
    while liars will be silenced.
speaker: Narrator

text:
O God, listen to my complaint.
    Protect my life from my enemies’ threats.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Hide me from the plots of this evil mob,
    from this gang of wrongdoers.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They sharpen their tongues like swords
    and aim their bitter words like arrows.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They shoot from ambush at the innocent,
    attacking suddenly and fearlessly.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They encourage each other to do evil
    and plan how to set their traps in secret.
    “Who will ever notice?” they ask.
speaker: Narrator

text:
As they plot their crimes, they say,
    “We have devised the perfect plan!”
    Yes, the human heart and mind are cunning.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But God himself will shoot them with his arrows,
    suddenly striking them down.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Their own tongues will ruin them,
    and all who see them will shake their heads in scorn.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
The godly will rejoice in the Lord
    and find shelter in him.
And those who do what is right
    will praise him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
What mighty praise, O God,
    belongs to you in Zion.
We will fulfill our vows to you,
speaker: Narrator

text:
for you answer our prayers.
    All of us must come to you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Though we are overwhelmed by our sins,
    you forgive them all.
speaker: Narrator

text:
What joy for those you choose to bring near,
    those who live in your holy courts.
What festivities await us
    inside your holy Temple.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You faithfully answer our prayers with awesome deeds,
    O God our savior.
You are the hope of everyone on earth,
    even those who sail on distant seas.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You formed the mountains by your power
    and armed yourself with mighty strength.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You quieted the raging oceans
    with their pounding waves
    and silenced the shouting of the nations.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Those who live at the ends of the earth
    stand in awe of your wonders.
From where the sun rises to where it sets,
    you inspire shouts of joy.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You take care of the earth and water it,
    making it rich and fertile.
The river of God has plenty of water;
    it provides a bountiful harvest of grain,
    for you have ordered it so.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You drench the plowed ground with rain,
    melting the clods and leveling the ridges.
You soften the earth with showers
    and bless its abundant crops.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You crown the year with a bountiful harvest;
    even the hard pathways overflow with abundance.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The grasslands of the wilderness become a lush pasture,
    and the hillsides blossom with joy.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The meadows are clothed with flocks of sheep,
    and the valleys are carpeted with grain.
    They all shout and sing for joy!
speaker: Narrator

text: Shout joyful praises to God, all the earth!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Sing about the glory of his name!
    Tell the world how glorious he is.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Say to God, “How awesome are your deeds!
    Your enemies cringe before your mighty power.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Come and see what our God has done,
    what awesome miracles he performs for people!
speaker: Narrator

text:
He made a dry path through the Red Sea,
    and his people went across on foot.
    There we rejoiced in him.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Let the whole world bless our God
    and loudly sing his praises.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Our lives are in his hands,
    and he keeps our feet from stumbling.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You have tested us, O God;
    you have purified us like silver.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You captured us in your net
    and laid the burden of slavery on our backs.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then you put a leader over us.
    We went through fire and flood,
    but you brought us to a place of great abundance.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Now I come to your Temple with burnt offerings
    to fulfill the vows I made to you—
speaker: Narrator

text:
yes, the sacred vows that I made
    when I was in deep trouble.
speaker: Narrator

text:
That is why I am sacrificing burnt offerings to you—
    the best of my rams as a pleasing aroma,
    and a sacrifice of bulls and male goats. Interlude
speaker: Narrator

text:
Come and listen, all you who fear God,
    and I will tell you what he did for me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For I cried out to him for help,
    praising him as I spoke.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If I had not confessed the sin in my heart,
    the Lord would not have listened.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But God did listen!
    He paid attention to my prayer.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Praise God, who did not ignore my prayer
    or withdraw his unfailing love from me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
May God be merciful and bless us.
    May his face smile with favor on us. Interlude
speaker: Narrator

text:
May your ways be known throughout the earth,
    your saving power among people everywhere.
speaker: Narrator

text:
May the nations praise you, O God.
    Yes, may all the nations praise you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let the whole world sing for joy,
    because you govern the nations with justice
    and guide the people of the whole world. Interlude
speaker: Narrator

text:
May the nations praise you, O God.
    Yes, may all the nations praise you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then the earth will yield its harvests,
    and God, our God, will richly bless us.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yes, God will bless us,
    and people all over the world will fear him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Rise up, O God, and scatter your enemies.
    Let those who hate God run for their lives.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Blow them away like smoke.
    Melt them like wax in a fire.
    Let the wicked perish in the presence of God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But let the godly rejoice.
    Let them be glad in God’s presence.
    Let them be filled with joy.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Sing praises to God and to his name!
    Sing loud praises to him who rides the clouds.
His name is the Lord—
    rejoice in his presence!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Father to the fatherless, defender of widows—
    this is God, whose dwelling is holy.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
O God, when you led your people out from Egypt,
    when you marched through the dry wasteland, Interlude
speaker: Narrator

text:
the earth trembled, and the heavens poured down rain
    before you, the God of Sinai,
    before God, the God of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You sent abundant rain, O God,
    to refresh the weary land.
speaker: Narrator

text:
There your people finally settled,
    and with a bountiful harvest, O God,
    you provided for your needy people.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord gives the word,
    and a great army brings the good news.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Enemy kings and their armies flee,
    while the women of Israel divide the plunder.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Even those who lived among the sheepfolds found treasures—
    doves with wings of silver
    and feathers of gold.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Almighty scattered the enemy kings
    like a blowing snowstorm on Mount Zalmon.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The mountains of Bashan are majestic,
    with many peaks stretching high into the sky.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Why do you look with envy, O rugged mountains,
    at Mount Zion, where God has chosen to live,
    where the Lord himself will live forever?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Surrounded by unnumbered thousands of chariots,
    the Lord came from Mount Sinai into his sanctuary.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When you ascended to the heights,
    you led a crowd of captives.
You received gifts from the people,
    even from those who rebelled against you.
    Now the Lord God will live among us there.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Praise the Lord; praise God our savior!
    For each day he carries us in his arms. Interlude
speaker: Narrator

text:
Our God is a God who saves!
    The Sovereign Lord rescues us from death.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But God will smash the heads of his enemies,
    crushing the skulls of those who love their guilty ways.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord says, “I will bring my enemies down from Bashan;
    I will bring them up from the depths of the sea.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You, my people, will wash your feet in their blood,
    and even your dogs will get their share!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your procession has come into view, O God—
    the procession of my God and King as he goes into the sanctuary.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Singers are in front, musicians behind;
    between them are young women playing tambourines.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Praise God, all you people of Israel;
    praise the Lord, the source of Israel’s life.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Look, the little tribe of Benjamin leads the way.
    Then comes a great throng of rulers from Judah
    and all the rulers of Zebulun and Naphtali.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Summon your might, O God.
    Display your power, O God, as you have in the past.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The kings of the earth are bringing tribute
    to your Temple in Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Rebuke these enemy nations—
    these wild animals lurking in the reeds,
    this herd of bulls among the weaker calves.
Make them bring bars of silver in humble tribute.
    Scatter the nations that delight in war.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let Egypt come with gifts of precious metals;
    let Ethiopia bring tribute to God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Sing to God, you kingdoms of the earth.
    Sing praises to the Lord. Interlude
speaker: Narrator

text:
Sing to the one who rides across the ancient heavens,
    his mighty voice thundering from the sky.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
God is awesome in his sanctuary.
    The God of Israel gives power and strength to his people.
Praise be to God!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Save me, O God,
    for the floodwaters are up to my neck.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Deeper and deeper I sink into the mire;
    I can’t find a foothold.
I am in deep water,
    and the floods overwhelm me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I am exhausted from crying for help;
    my throat is parched.
My eyes are swollen with weeping,
    waiting for my God to help me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Those who hate me without cause
    outnumber the hairs on my head.
Many enemies try to destroy me with lies,
    demanding that I give back what I didn’t steal.
speaker: Narrator

text:
O God, you know how foolish I am;
    my sins cannot be hidden from you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Don’t let those who trust in you be ashamed because of me,
    O Sovereign Lord of Heaven’s Armies.
Don’t let me cause them to be humiliated,
    O God of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For I endure insults for your sake;
    humiliation is written all over my face.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Even my own brothers pretend they don’t know me;
    they treat me like a stranger.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Passion for your house has consumed me,
    and the insults of those who insult you have fallen on me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When I weep and fast,
    they scoff at me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When I dress in burlap to show sorrow,
    they make fun of me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I am the favorite topic of town gossip,
    and all the drunks sing about me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But I keep praying to you, Lord,
    hoping this time you will show me favor.
In your unfailing love, O God,
    answer my prayer with your sure salvation.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Rescue me from the mud;
    don’t let me sink any deeper!
Save me from those who hate me,
    and pull me from these deep waters.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Don’t let the floods overwhelm me,
    or the deep waters swallow me,
    or the pit of death devour me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Answer my prayers, O Lord,
    for your unfailing love is wonderful.
Take care of me,
    for your mercy is so plentiful.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Don’t hide from your servant;
    answer me quickly, for I am in deep trouble!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Come and redeem me;
    free me from my enemies.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You know of my shame, scorn, and disgrace.
    You see all that my enemies are doing.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Their insults have broken my heart,
    and I am in despair.
If only one person would show some pity;
    if only one would turn and comfort me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But instead, they give me poison for food;
    they offer me sour wine for my thirst.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let the bountiful table set before them become a snare
    and their prosperity become a trap.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let their eyes go blind so they cannot see,
    and make their bodies shake continually.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Pour out your fury on them;
    consume them with your burning anger.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let their homes become desolate
    and their tents be deserted.
speaker: Narrator

text:
To the one you have punished, they add insult to injury;
    they add to the pain of those you have hurt.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Pile their sins up high,
    and don’t let them go free.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Erase their names from the Book of Life;
    don’t let them be counted among the righteous.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I am suffering and in pain.
    Rescue me, O God, by your saving power.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then I will praise God’s name with singing,
    and I will honor him with thanksgiving.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For this will please the Lord more than sacrificing cattle,
    more than presenting a bull with its horns and hooves.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The humble will see their God at work and be glad.
    Let all who seek God’s help be encouraged.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For the Lord hears the cries of the needy;
    he does not despise his imprisoned people.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Praise him, O heaven and earth,
    the seas and all that move in them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For God will save Jerusalem
    and rebuild the towns of Judah.
His people will live there
    and settle in their own land.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The descendants of those who obey him will inherit the land,
    and those who love him will live there in safety.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Please, God, rescue me!
    Come quickly, Lord, and help me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
May those who try to kill me
    be humiliated and put to shame.
May those who take delight in my trouble
    be turned back in disgrace.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let them be horrified by their shame,
    for they said, “Aha! We’ve got him now!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
But may all who search for you
    be filled with joy and gladness in you.
May those who love your salvation
    repeatedly shout, “God is great!”
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
O Lord, I have come to you for protection;
    don’t let me be disgraced.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Save me and rescue me,
    for you do what is right.
Turn your ear to listen to me,
    and set me free.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Be my rock of safety
    where I can always hide.
Give the order to save me,
    for you are my rock and my fortress.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My God, rescue me from the power of the wicked,
    from the clutches of cruel oppressors.
speaker: Narrator

text:
O Lord, you alone are my hope.
    I’ve trusted you, O Lord, from childhood.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
My life is an example to many,
    because you have been my strength and protection.
speaker: Narrator

text:
That is why I can never stop praising you;
    I declare your glory all day long.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And now, in my old age, don’t set me aside.
    Don’t abandon me when my strength is failing.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For my enemies are whispering against me.
    They are plotting together to kill me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They say, “God has abandoned him.
    Let’s go and get him,
    for no one will help him now.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
O God, don’t stay away.
    My God, please hurry to help me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Bring disgrace and destruction on my accusers.
    Humiliate and shame those who want to harm me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But I will keep on hoping for your help;
    I will praise you more and more.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will tell everyone about your righteousness.
    All day long I will proclaim your saving power,
    though I am not skilled with words.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will praise your mighty deeds, O Sovereign Lord.
    I will tell everyone that you alone are just.
speaker: Narrator

text:
O God, you have taught me from my earliest childhood,
    and I constantly tell others about the wonderful things you do.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Now that I am old and gray,
    do not abandon me, O God.
Let me proclaim your power to this new generation,
    your mighty miracles to all who come after me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your righteousness, O God, reaches to the highest heavens.
    You have done such wonderful things.
    Who can compare with you, O God?
speaker: Narrator

text:
You have allowed me to suffer much hardship,
    but you will restore me to life again
    and lift me up from the depths of the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You will restore me to even greater honor
    and comfort me once again.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then I will praise you with music on the harp,
    because you are faithful to your promises, O my God.
I will sing praises to you with a lyre,
    O Holy One of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will shout for joy and sing your praises,
    for you have ransomed me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will tell about your righteous deeds
    all day long,
for everyone who tried to hurt me
    has been shamed and humiliated.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Give your love of justice to the king, O God,
    and righteousness to the king’s son.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Help him judge your people in the right way;
    let the poor always be treated fairly.
speaker: Narrator

text:
May the mountains yield prosperity for all,
    and may the hills be fruitful.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Help him to defend the poor,
    to rescue the children of the needy,
    and to crush their oppressors.
speaker: Narrator

text:
May they fear you as long as the sun shines,
    as long as the moon remains in the sky.
    Yes, forever!
speaker: Narrator

text:
May the king’s rule be refreshing like spring rain on freshly cut grass,
    like the showers that water the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
May all the godly flourish during his reign.
    May there be abundant prosperity until the moon is no more.
speaker: Narrator

text:
May he reign from sea to sea,
    and from the Euphrates River to the ends of the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Desert nomads will bow before him;
    his enemies will fall before him in the dust.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The western kings of Tarshish and other distant lands
    will bring him tribute.
The eastern kings of Sheba and Seba
    will bring him gifts.
speaker: Narrator

text:
All kings will bow before him,
    and all nations will serve him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He will rescue the poor when they cry to him;
    he will help the oppressed, who have no one to defend them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He feels pity for the weak and the needy,
    and he will rescue them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He will redeem them from oppression and violence,
    for their lives are precious to him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Long live the king!
    May the gold of Sheba be given to him.
May the people always pray for him
    and bless him all day long.
speaker: Narrator

text:
May there be abundant grain throughout the land,
    flourishing even on the hilltops.
May the fruit trees flourish like the trees of Lebanon,
    and may the people thrive like grass in a field.
speaker: Narrator

text:
May the king’s name endure forever;
    may it continue as long as the sun shines.
May all nations be blessed through him
    and bring him praise.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Praise the Lord God, the God of Israel,
    who alone does such wonderful things.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Praise his glorious name forever!
    Let the whole earth be filled with his glory.
Amen and amen!
speaker: Narrator

text: (This ends the prayers of David son of Jesse.)
speaker: Narrator

text:
Truly God is good to Israel,
    to those whose hearts are pure.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But as for me, I almost lost my footing.
    My feet were slipping, and I was almost gone.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For I envied the proud
    when I saw them prosper despite their wickedness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They seem to live such painless lives;
    their bodies are so healthy and strong.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They don’t have troubles like other people;
    they’re not plagued with problems like everyone else.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They wear pride like a jeweled necklace
    and clothe themselves with cruelty.
speaker: Narrator

text:
These fat cats have everything
    their hearts could ever wish for!
speaker: Narrator

text:
They scoff and speak only evil;
    in their pride they seek to crush others.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They boast against the very heavens,
    and their words strut throughout the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And so the people are dismayed and confused,
    drinking in all their words.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“What does God know?” they ask.
    “Does the Most High even know what’s happening?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Look at these wicked people—
    enjoying a life of ease while their riches multiply.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Did I keep my heart pure for nothing?
    Did I keep myself innocent for no reason?
speaker: Narrator

text:
I get nothing but trouble all day long;
    every morning brings me pain.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If I had really spoken this way to others,
    I would have been a traitor to your people.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So I tried to understand why the wicked prosper.
    But what a difficult task it is!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then I went into your sanctuary, O God,
    and I finally understood the destiny of the wicked.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Truly, you put them on a slippery path
    and send them sliding over the cliff to destruction.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In an instant they are destroyed,
    completely swept away by terrors.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When you arise, O Lord,
    you will laugh at their silly ideas
    as a person laughs at dreams in the morning.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then I realized that my heart was bitter,
    and I was all torn up inside.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I was so foolish and ignorant—
    I must have seemed like a senseless animal to you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yet I still belong to you;
    you hold my right hand.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You guide me with your counsel,
    leading me to a glorious destiny.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whom have I in heaven but you?
    I desire you more than anything on earth.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Those who desert him will perish,
    for you destroy those who abandon you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But as for me, how good it is to be near God!
    I have made the Sovereign Lord my shelter,
    and I will tell everyone about the wonderful things you do.
speaker: Narrator

text:
O God, why have you rejected us so long?
    Why is your anger so intense against the sheep of your own pasture?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Remember that we are the people you chose long ago,
    the tribe you redeemed as your own special possession!
    And remember Jerusalem, your home here on earth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Walk through the awful ruins of the city;
    see how the enemy has destroyed your sanctuary.
speaker: Narrator

text:
There your enemies shouted their victorious battle cries;
    there they set up their battle standards.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They swung their axes
    like woodcutters in a forest.
speaker: Narrator

text:
With axes and picks,
    they smashed the carved paneling.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They burned your sanctuary to the ground.
    They defiled the place that bears your name.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then they thought, “Let’s destroy everything!”
    So they burned down all the places where God was worshiped.
speaker: Narrator

text:
We no longer see your miraculous signs.
    All the prophets are gone,
    and no one can tell us when it will end.
speaker: Narrator

text:
How long, O God, will you allow our enemies to insult you?
    Will you let them dishonor your name forever?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Why do you hold back your strong right hand?
    Unleash your powerful fist and destroy them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You, O God, are my king from ages past,
    bringing salvation to the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You split the sea by your strength
    and smashed the heads of the sea monsters.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You crushed the heads of Leviathan
    and let the desert animals eat him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You caused the springs and streams to gush forth,
    and you dried up rivers that never run dry.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Both day and night belong to you;
    you made the starlight and the sun.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You set the boundaries of the earth,
    and you made both summer and winter.
speaker: Narrator

text:
See how these enemies insult you, Lord.
    A foolish nation has dishonored your name.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Don’t let these wild beasts destroy your turtledoves.
    Don’t forget your suffering people forever.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Remember your covenant promises,
    for the land is full of darkness and violence!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Don’t let the downtrodden be humiliated again.
    Instead, let the poor and needy praise your name.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Arise, O God, and defend your cause.
    Remember how these fools insult you all day long.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Don’t overlook what your enemies have said
    or their growing uproar.
speaker: Narrator

text:
We thank you, O God!
    We give thanks because you are near.
    People everywhere tell of your wonderful deeds.
speaker: Narrator

text:
God says, “At the time I have planned,
    I will bring justice against the wicked.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When the earth quakes and its people live in turmoil,
    I am the one who keeps its foundations firm. Interlude
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I warned the proud, ‘Stop your boasting!’
    I told the wicked, ‘Don’t raise your fists!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Don’t raise your fists in defiance at the heavens
    or speak with such arrogance.’”
speaker: Narrator

text:
For no one on earth—from east or west,
    or even from the wilderness—
    should raise a defiant fist.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It is God alone who judges;
    he decides who will rise and who will fall.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For the Lord holds a cup in his hand
    that is full of foaming wine mixed with spices.
He pours out the wine in judgment,
    and all the wicked must drink it,
    draining it to the dregs.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But as for me, I will always proclaim what God has done;
    I will sing praises to the God of Jacob.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For God says, “I will break the strength of the wicked,
    but I will increase the power of the godly.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
God is honored in Judah;
    his name is great in Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Jerusalem is where he lives;
    Mount Zion is his home.
speaker: Narrator

text:
There he has broken the fiery arrows of the enemy,
    the shields and swords and weapons of war. Interlude
speaker: Narrator

text:
You are glorious and more majestic
    than the everlasting mountains.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Our boldest enemies have been plundered.
    They lie before us in the sleep of death.
    No warrior could lift a hand against us.
speaker: Narrator

text:
At the blast of your breath, O God of Jacob,
    their horses and chariots lay still.
speaker: Narrator

text:
No wonder you are greatly feared!
    Who can stand before you when your anger explodes?
speaker: Narrator

text:
From heaven you sentenced your enemies;
    the earth trembled and stood silent before you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You stand up to judge those who do evil, O God,
    and to rescue the oppressed of the earth. Interlude
speaker: Narrator

text:
Human defiance only enhances your glory,
    for you use it as a weapon.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Make vows to the Lord your God, and keep them.
    Let everyone bring tribute to the Awesome One.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For he breaks the pride of princes,
    and the kings of the earth fear him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I cry out to God; yes, I shout.
    Oh, that God would listen to me!
speaker: Narrator

text:
When I was in deep trouble,
    I searched for the Lord.
All night long I prayed, with hands lifted toward heaven,
    but my soul was not comforted.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I think of God, and I moan,
    overwhelmed with longing for his help. Interlude
speaker: Narrator

text:
You don’t let me sleep.
    I am too distressed even to pray!
speaker: Narrator

text:
I think of the good old days,
    long since ended,
speaker: Narrator

text:
when my nights were filled with joyful songs.
    I search my soul and ponder the difference now.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Has the Lord rejected me forever?
    Will he never again be kind to me?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Is his unfailing love gone forever?
    Have his promises permanently failed?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Has God forgotten to be gracious?
    Has he slammed the door on his compassion? Interlude
speaker: Narrator

text:
And I said, “This is my fate;
    the Most High has turned his hand against me.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
But then I recall all you have done, O Lord;
    I remember your wonderful deeds of long ago.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They are constantly in my thoughts.
    I cannot stop thinking about your mighty works.
speaker: Narrator

text:
O God, your ways are holy.
    Is there any god as mighty as you?
speaker: Narrator

text:
You are the God of great wonders!
    You demonstrate your awesome power among the nations.
speaker: Narrator

text:
By your strong arm, you redeemed your people,
    the descendants of Jacob and Joseph. Interlude
speaker: Narrator

text:
When the Red Sea saw you, O God,
    its waters looked and trembled!
    The sea quaked to its very depths.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

text:
Your road led through the sea,
    your pathway through the mighty waters—
    a pathway no one knew was there!
speaker: Narrator

text:
You led your people along that road like a flock of sheep,
    with Moses and Aaron as their shepherds.
speaker: Narrator

text:
O my people, listen to my instructions.
    Open your ears to what I am saying,
speaker: Narrator

text:
for I will speak to you in a parable.
I will teach you hidden lessons from our past—
speaker: Narrator

text:
stories we have heard and known,
    stories our ancestors handed down to us.
speaker: Narrator

text:
We will not hide these truths from our children;
    we will tell the next generation
about the glorious deeds of the Lord,
    about his power and his mighty wonders.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For he issued his laws to Jacob;
    he gave his instructions to Israel.
He commanded our ancestors
    to teach them to their children,
speaker: Narrator

text:
so the next generation might know them—
    even the children not yet born—
    and they in turn will teach their own children.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So each generation should set its hope anew on God,
    not forgetting his glorious miracles
    and obeying his commands.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then they will not be like their ancestors—
    stubborn, rebellious, and unfaithful,
    refusing to give their hearts to God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The warriors of Ephraim, though armed with bows,
    turned their backs and fled on the day of battle.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They did not keep God’s covenant
    and refused to live by his instructions.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They forgot what he had done—
    the great wonders he had shown them,
speaker: Narrator

text:
the miracles he did for their ancestors
    on the plain of Zoan in the land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For he divided the sea and led them through,
    making the water stand up like walls!
speaker: Narrator

text:
In the daytime he led them by a cloud,
    and all night by a pillar of fire.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He split open the rocks in the wilderness
    to give them water, as from a gushing spring.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He made streams pour from the rock,
    making the waters flow down like a river!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yet they kept on sinning against him,
    rebelling against the Most High in the desert.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They stubbornly tested God in their hearts,
    demanding the foods they craved.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They even spoke against God himself, saying,
    “God can’t give us food in the wilderness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yes, he can strike a rock so water gushes out,
    but he can’t give his people bread and meat.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
When the Lord heard them, he was furious.
    The fire of his wrath burned against Jacob.
    Yes, his anger rose against Israel,
speaker: Narrator

text:
for they did not believe God
    or trust him to care for them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But he commanded the skies to open;
    he opened the doors of heaven.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He rained down manna for them to eat;
    he gave them bread from heaven.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They ate the food of angels!
    God gave them all they could hold.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He released the east wind in the heavens
    and guided the south wind by his mighty power.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He rained down meat as thick as dust—
    birds as plentiful as the sand on the seashore!
speaker: Narrator

text:
He caused the birds to fall within their camp
    and all around their tents.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The people ate their fill.
    He gave them what they craved.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But before they satisfied their craving,
    while the meat was yet in their mouths,
speaker: Narrator

text:
the anger of God rose against them,
    and he killed their strongest men.
    He struck down the finest of Israel’s young men.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But in spite of this, the people kept sinning.
    Despite his wonders, they refused to trust him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So he ended their lives in failure,
    their years in terror.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When God began killing them,
    they finally sought him.
    They repented and took God seriously.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then they remembered that God was their rock,
    that God Most High was their redeemer.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But all they gave him was lip service;
    they lied to him with their tongues.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Their hearts were not loyal to him.
    They did not keep his covenant.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yet he was merciful and forgave their sins
    and did not destroy them all.
Many times he held back his anger
    and did not unleash his fury!
speaker: Narrator

text:
For he remembered that they were merely mortal,
    gone like a breath of wind that never returns.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Oh, how often they rebelled against him in the wilderness
    and grieved his heart in that dry wasteland.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Again and again they tested God’s patience
    and provoked the Holy One of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They did not remember his power
    and how he rescued them from their enemies.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They did not remember his miraculous signs in Egypt,
    his wonders on the plain of Zoan.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For he turned their rivers into blood,
    so no one could drink from the streams.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He sent vast swarms of flies to consume them
    and hordes of frogs to ruin them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He gave their crops to caterpillars;
    their harvest was consumed by locusts.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He destroyed their grapevines with hail
    and shattered their sycamore-figs with sleet.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He abandoned their cattle to the hail,
    their livestock to bolts of lightning.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He loosed on them his fierce anger—
    all his fury, rage, and hostility.
He dispatched against them
    a band of destroying angels.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
He killed the oldest son in each Egyptian family,
    the flower of youth throughout the land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But he led his own people like a flock of sheep,
    guiding them safely through the wilderness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He kept them safe so they were not afraid;
    but the sea covered their enemies.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He brought them to the border of his holy land,
    to this land of hills he had won for them.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
But they kept testing and rebelling against God Most High.
    They did not obey his laws.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They turned back and were as faithless as their parents.
    They were as undependable as a crooked bow.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They angered God by building shrines to other gods;
    they made him jealous with their idols.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When God heard them, he was very angry,
    and he completely rejected Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then he abandoned his dwelling at Shiloh,
    the Tabernacle where he had lived among the people.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He allowed the Ark of his might to be captured;
    he surrendered his glory into enemy hands.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He gave his people over to be butchered by the sword,
    because he was so angry with his own people—his special possession.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Their young men were killed by fire;
    their young women died before singing their wedding songs.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Their priests were slaughtered,
    and their widows could not mourn their deaths.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then the Lord rose up as though waking from sleep,
    like a warrior aroused from a drunken stupor.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He routed his enemies
    and sent them to eternal shame.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But he rejected Joseph’s descendants;
    he did not choose the tribe of Ephraim.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He chose instead the tribe of Judah,
    and Mount Zion, which he loved.
speaker: Narrator

text:
There he built his sanctuary as high as the heavens,
    as solid and enduring as the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He chose his servant David,
    calling him from the sheep pens.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He took David from tending the ewes and lambs
    and made him the shepherd of Jacob’s descendants—
    God’s own people, Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He cared for them with a true heart
    and led them with skillful hands.
speaker: Narrator

text:
O God, pagan nations have conquered your land,
    your special possession.
They have defiled your holy Temple
    and made Jerusalem a heap of ruins.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They have left the bodies of your servants
    as food for the birds of heaven.
The flesh of your godly ones
    has become food for the wild animals.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Blood has flowed like water all around Jerusalem;
    no one is left to bury the dead.
speaker: Narrator

text:
We are mocked by our neighbors,
    an object of scorn and derision to those around us.
speaker: Narrator

text:
O Lord, how long will you be angry with us? Forever?
    How long will your jealousy burn like fire?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Pour out your wrath on the nations that refuse to acknowledge you—
    on kingdoms that do not call upon your name.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For they have devoured your people Israel,
    making the land a desolate wilderness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not hold us guilty for the sins of our ancestors!
    Let your compassion quickly meet our needs,
    for we are on the brink of despair.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Help us, O God of our salvation!
    Help us for the glory of your name.
Save us and forgive our sins
    for the honor of your name.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Why should pagan nations be allowed to scoff,
    asking, “Where is their God?”
Show us your vengeance against the nations,
    for they have spilled the blood of your servants.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Listen to the moaning of the prisoners.
    Demonstrate your great power by saving those condemned to die.
speaker: Narrator

text:
O Lord, pay back our neighbors seven times
    for the scorn they have hurled at you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then we your people, the sheep of your pasture,
    will thank you forever and ever,
    praising your greatness from generation to generation.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Please listen, O Shepherd of Israel,
    you who lead Joseph’s descendants like a flock.
O God, enthroned above the cherubim,
    display your radiant glory
speaker: Narrator

text:
to Ephraim, Benjamin, and Manasseh.
Show us your mighty power.
    Come to rescue us!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Turn us again to yourself, O God.
    Make your face shine down upon us.
    Only then will we be saved.
speaker: Narrator

text:
O Lord God of Heaven’s Armies,
    how long will you be angry with our prayers?
speaker: Narrator

text:
You have fed us with sorrow
    and made us drink tears by the bucketful.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You have made us the scorn of neighboring nations.
    Our enemies treat us as a joke.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Turn us again to yourself, O God of Heaven’s Armies.
    Make your face shine down upon us.
    Only then will we be saved.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You brought us from Egypt like a grapevine;
    you drove away the pagan nations and transplanted us into your land.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You cleared the ground for us,
    and we took root and filled the land.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Our shade covered the mountains;
    our branches covered the mighty cedars.
speaker: Narrator

text:
We spread our branches west to the Mediterranean Sea;
    our shoots spread east to the Euphrates River.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But now, why have you broken down our walls
    so that all who pass by may steal our fruit?
speaker: Narrator

text:
The wild boar from the forest devours it,
    and the wild animals feed on it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Come back, we beg you, O God of Heaven’s Armies.
    Look down from heaven and see our plight.
Take care of this grapevine
speaker: Narrator

text:
that you yourself have planted,
    this son you have raised for yourself.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For we are chopped up and burned by our enemies.
    May they perish at the sight of your frown.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Strengthen the man you love,
    the son of your choice.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then we will never abandon you again.
    Revive us so we can call on your name once more.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Turn us again to yourself, O Lord God of Heaven’s Armies.
    Make your face shine down upon us.
    Only then will we be saved.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Sing praises to God, our strength.
    Sing to the God of Jacob.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Sing! Beat the tambourine.
    Play the sweet lyre and the harp.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Blow the ram’s horn at new moon,
    and again at full moon to call a festival!
speaker: Narrator

text:
For this is required by the decrees of Israel;
    it is a regulation of the God of Jacob.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He made it a law for Israel
    when he attacked Egypt to set us free.
I heard an unknown voice say,
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Now I will take the load from your shoulders;
    I will free your hands from their heavy tasks.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
“Listen to me, O my people, while I give you stern warnings.
    O Israel, if you would only listen to me!
speaker: Narrator

text:
You must never have a foreign god;
    you must not bow down before a false god.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For it was I, the Lord your God,
    who rescued you from the land of Egypt.
    Open your mouth wide, and I will fill it with good things.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“But no, my people wouldn’t listen.
    Israel did not want me around.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So I let them follow their own stubborn desires,
    living according to their own ideas.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Oh, that my people would listen to me!
    Oh, that Israel would follow me, walking in my paths!
speaker: Narrator

text:
How quickly I would then subdue their enemies!
    How soon my hands would be upon their foes!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Those who hate the Lord would cringe before him;
    they would be doomed forever.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But I would feed you with the finest wheat.
    I would satisfy you with wild honey from the rock.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
God presides over heaven’s court;
    he pronounces judgment on the heavenly beings:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“How long will you hand down unjust decisions
    by favoring the wicked? Interlude
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Give justice to the poor and the orphan;
    uphold the rights of the oppressed and the destitute.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Rescue the poor and helpless;
    deliver them from the grasp of evil people.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But these oppressors know nothing;
    they are so ignorant!
They wander about in darkness,
    while the whole world is shaken to the core.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I say, ‘You are gods;
    you are all children of the Most High.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But you will die like mere mortals
    and fall like every other ruler.’”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Rise up, O God, and judge the earth,
    for all the nations belong to you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
O God, do not be silent!
    Do not be deaf.
    Do not be quiet, O God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Don’t you hear the uproar of your enemies?
    Don’t you see that your arrogant enemies are rising up?
speaker: Narrator

text:
They devise crafty schemes against your people;
    they conspire against your precious ones.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Come,” they say, “let us wipe out Israel as a nation.
    We will destroy the very memory of its existence.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yes, this was their unanimous decision.
    They signed a treaty as allies against you—
speaker: Narrator

text:
these Edomites and Ishmaelites;
    Moabites and Hagrites;
speaker: Narrator

text:
Gebalites, Ammonites, and Amalekites;
    and people from Philistia and Tyre.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Assyria has joined them, too,
    and is allied with the descendants of Lot. Interlude
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do to them as you did to the Midianites
    and as you did to Sisera and Jabin at the Kishon River.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They were destroyed at Endor,
    and their decaying corpses fertilized the soil.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let their mighty nobles die as Oreb and Zeeb did.
    Let all their princes die like Zebah and Zalmunna,
speaker: Narrator

text:
for they said, “Let us seize for our own use
    these pasturelands of God!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
O my God, scatter them like tumbleweed,
    like chaff before the wind!
speaker: Narrator

text:
As a fire burns a forest
    and as a flame sets mountains ablaze,
speaker: Narrator

text:
chase them with your fierce storm;
    terrify them with your tempest.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Utterly disgrace them
    until they submit to your name, O Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let them be ashamed and terrified forever.
    Let them die in disgrace.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then they will learn that you alone are called the Lord,
    that you alone are the Most High,
    supreme over all the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
How lovely is your dwelling place,
    O Lord of Heaven’s Armies.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I long, yes, I faint with longing
    to enter the courts of the Lord.
With my whole being, body and soul,
    I will shout joyfully to the living God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Even the sparrow finds a home,
    and the swallow builds her nest and raises her young
at a place near your altar,
    O Lord of Heaven’s Armies, my King and my God!
speaker: Narrator

text:
What joy for those who can live in your house,
    always singing your praises. Interlude
speaker: Narrator

text:
What joy for those whose strength comes from the Lord,
    who have set their minds on a pilgrimage to Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When they walk through the Valley of Weeping,
    it will become a place of refreshing springs.
    The autumn rains will clothe it with blessings.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They will continue to grow stronger,
    and each of them will appear before God in Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text:
O Lord God of Heaven’s Armies, hear my prayer.
    Listen, O God of Jacob. Interlude
speaker: Narrator

text:
O God, look with favor upon the king, our shield!
    Show favor to the one you have anointed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A single day in your courts
    is better than a thousand anywhere else!
I would rather be a gatekeeper in the house of my God
    than live the good life in the homes of the wicked.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For the Lord God is our sun and our shield.
    He gives us grace and glory.
The Lord will withhold no good thing
    from those who do what is right.
speaker: Narrator

text:
O Lord of Heaven’s Armies,
    what joy for those who trust in you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Lord, you poured out blessings on your land!
    You restored the fortunes of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You forgave the guilt of your people—
    yes, you covered all their sins. Interlude
speaker: Narrator

text:
You held back your fury.
    You kept back your blazing anger.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Now restore us again, O God of our salvation.
    Put aside your anger against us once more.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Will you be angry with us always?
    Will you prolong your wrath to all generations?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Won’t you revive us again,
    so your people can rejoice in you?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Show us your unfailing love, O Lord,
    and grant us your salvation.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I listen carefully to what God the Lord is saying,
    for he speaks peace to his faithful people.
    But let them not return to their foolish ways.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Surely his salvation is near to those who fear him,
    so our land will be filled with his glory.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Unfailing love and truth have met together.
    Righteousness and peace have kissed!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Truth springs up from the earth,
    and righteousness smiles down from heaven.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yes, the Lord pours down his blessings.
    Our land will yield its bountiful harvest.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Righteousness goes as a herald before him,
    preparing the way for his steps.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Bend down, O Lord, and hear my prayer;
    answer me, for I need your help.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Protect me, for I am devoted to you.
    Save me, for I serve you and trust you.
    You are my God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Be merciful to me, O Lord,
    for I am calling on you constantly.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Give me happiness, O Lord,
    for I give myself to you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
O Lord, you are so good, so ready to forgive,
    so full of unfailing love for all who ask for your help.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Listen closely to my prayer, O Lord;
    hear my urgent cry.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will call to you whenever I’m in trouble,
    and you will answer me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
No pagan god is like you, O Lord.
    None can do what you do!
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
For you are great and perform wonderful deeds.
    You alone are God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Teach me your ways, O Lord,
    that I may live according to your truth!
Grant me purity of heart,
    so that I may honor you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
With all my heart I will praise you, O Lord my God.
    I will give glory to your name forever,
speaker: Narrator

text:
for your love for me is very great.
    You have rescued me from the depths of death.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
But you, O Lord,
    are a God of compassion and mercy,
slow to get angry
    and filled with unfailing love and faithfulness.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Send me a sign of your favor.
    Then those who hate me will be put to shame,
    for you, O Lord, help and comfort me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
On the holy mountain
    stands the city founded by the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He loves the city of Jerusalem
    more than any other city in Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
O city of God,
    what glorious things are said of you! Interlude
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will count Egypt and Babylon among those who know me—
    also Philistia and Tyre, and even distant Ethiopia.
    They have all become citizens of Jerusalem!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Regarding Jerusalem it will be said,
    “Everyone enjoys the rights of citizenship there.”
    And the Most High will personally bless this city.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When the Lord registers the nations, he will say,
